questions.text: A 68-year-old man with end-stage renal disease misses several dialysis appointments. A routine blood test reveals a serum potassium level of 7.2 mEq/L (Normal: 3.5-5.0 mEq/L). This change in extracellular potassium concentration will have which of the following effects on the resting membrane potential (RMP) of his cardiomyocytes?

options.label: A
options.text: The RMP will become more negative (hyperpolarize).

options.label: B
options.text: The RMP will become less negative (depolarize).

options.label: C
options.text: The RMP will be primarily determined by the sodium equilibrium potential.

options.label: D
options.text: The RMP will remain unchanged.

questions.correct_answer: B. The RMP will become less negative (depolarize).

questions.text: During a vigorous workout, a 25-year-old weightlifter experiences forceful muscle contractions. Which of the following events occurs at the level of the sarcomere during this process?

options.label: A
options.text: The A band shortens as myosin filaments slide past actin.

options.label: B
options.text: Calcium binds to myosin heads, causing a conformational change.

options.label: C
options.text: ATP binding to the myosin head causes the power stroke.

options.label: D
options.text: The I band and H zone both shorten.

questions.correct_answer: D. The I band and H zone both shorten.

questions.text: A patient experiences a sharp, localized pain sensation immediately after touching a hot stove. This initial, rapid pain signal is transmitted to the central nervous system primarily by which type of nerve fiber?

options.label: A
options.text: A-alpha (Aα) fibers

options.label: B
options.text: A-delta (Aδ) fibers

options.label: C
options.text: C fibers

options.label: D
options.text: B fibers

questions.correct_answer: B. A-delta (Aδ) fibers

questions.text: A biopsy of the gastrocnemius muscle from an elite marathon runner would most likely show a predominance of which type of muscle fiber?

options.label: A
options.text: Type I fibers with high myoglobin content and high mitochondrial density.

options.label: B
options.text: Type IIb fibers with low myoglobin content and high glycolytic capacity.

options.label: C
options.text: Type IIa fibers with high myoglobin content and high glycolytic capacity.

options.label: D
options.text: Fibers with a low capacity for oxidative phosphorylation.

questions.correct_answer: A. Type I fibers with high myoglobin content and high mitochondrial density.

questions.text: A 60-year-old veteran who underwent a left below-knee amputation a year ago reports experiencing a cramping sensation in his amputated foot. The most widely accepted neurological basis for this phantom limb sensation is:

options.label: A
options.text: Ongoing nerve impulses from the severed nerves in the residual limb (neuromas).

options.label: B
options.text: Reorganization of the somatosensory cortex, where cortical areas for the hand and face invade the area formerly representing the foot.

options.label: C
options.text: Psychological expectation and memory of the limb.

options.label: D
options.text: Spontaneous firing of spinal cord neurons in the dorsal horn.

questions.correct_answer: B. Reorganization of the somatosensory cortex, where cortical areas for the hand and face invade the area formerly representing the foot.

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with Klüver-Bucy syndrome after recovering from herpes simplex encephalitis. Which of the following symptoms is most characteristic of this syndrome and is caused by bilateral lesions to the amygdala?

options.label: A
options.text: Anterograde amnesia

options.label: B
options.text: Aphasia

options.label: C
options.text: Hyperphagia and placidity

options.label: D
options.text: Hemispatial neglect

questions.correct_answer: C. Hyperphagia and placidity

questions.text: When a photon of light strikes a photoreceptor cell in the retina, it initiates a cascade that leads to a change in the cell's membrane potential. Which of the following correctly describes this process?

options.label: A
options.text: Light causes depolarization of the rod cell by opening cGMP-gated sodium channels.

options.label: B
options.text: Light activates transducin, which leads to increased levels of intracellular cGMP.

options.label: C
options.text: Light causes hyperpolarization of the rod cell by closing cGMP-gated sodium channels.

options.label: D
options.text: Light leads to an increase in neurotransmitter release from the photoreceptor terminal.

questions.correct_answer: C. Light causes hyperpolarization of the rod cell by closing cGMP-gated sodium channels.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with recurrent peptic ulcers that are resistant to standard therapy and chronic diarrhea. An upper endoscopy reveals multiple ulcers in the duodenum and jejunum. A fasting serum gastrin level is markedly elevated. This patient's symptoms are most likely caused by the overproduction of gastrin from which of the following sources?

options.label: A
options.text: G cells in the gastric antrum

options.label: B
options.text: Parietal cells in the gastric fundus

options.label: C
options.text: A pancreatic neuroendocrine tumor

options.label: D
options.text: D cells in the gastric antrum

questions.correct_answer: C. A pancreatic neuroendocrine tumor

questions.text: A traveler returning from a region with poor sanitation develops voluminous, "rice-water" stool and becomes severely dehydrated. The toxin produced by Vibrio cholerae causes this secretory diarrhea by which of the following mechanisms?

options.label: A
options.text: It inhibits the Na+/K+ ATPase pump in enterocytes.

options.label: B
options.text: It forms pores in the enterocyte membrane, causing fluid leakage.

options.label: C
options.text: It irreversibly activates a Gs protein, leading to a sustained increase in intracellular cAMP.

options.label: D
options.text: It blocks the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) chloride channel.

questions.correct_answer: C. It irreversibly activates a Gs protein, leading to a sustained increase in intracellular cAMP.

questions.text: On a Wiggers diagram representing the cardiac cycle of the left ventricle, the mitral valve opens at the point where:

options.label: A
options.text: Left ventricular pressure exceeds aortic pressure

options.label: B
options.text: Left atrial pressure exceeds left ventricular pressure

options.label: C
options.text: The T wave of the ECG occurs

options.label: D
options.text: The first heart sound (S1) is heard

questions.correct_answer: B. Left atrial pressure exceeds left ventricular pressure

questions.text: A healthy volunteer stands up quickly from a supine position. Which of the following represents the immediate physiological response mediated by the baroreflex?

options.label: A
options.text: Increased firing rate from carotid sinus baroreceptors leading to decreased sympathetic outflow.

options.label: B
options.text: Decreased firing rate from carotid sinus baroreceptors leading to increased sympathetic outflow and vasoconstriction.

options.label: C
options.text: Activation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system.

options.label: D
options.text: Increased parasympathetic output to the sinoatrial node.

questions.correct_answer: B. Decreased firing rate from carotid sinus baroreceptors leading to increased sympathetic outflow and vasoconstriction.

questions.text: A physical examination of a patient with right-sided heart failure reveals a prominent, pulsatile jugular vein. The pressure waveform analysis shows a large, pathological 'v' wave that obliterates the 'x' descent. This finding is most characteristic of:

options.label: A
options.text: Atrial fibrillation

options.label: B
options.text: Tricuspid stenosis

options.label: C
options.text: Cardiac tamponade

options.label: D
options.text: Tricuspid regurgitation

questions.correct_answer: D. Tricuspid regurgitation

questions.text: A patient with septic shock develops a fever of 39.5°C (103.1°F) and a metabolic acidosis with a blood pH of 7.20. These changes will affect oxygen transport by causing which of the following shifts in the oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve?

options.label: A
options.text: A leftward shift, increasing hemoglobin's affinity for oxygen.

options.label: B
options.text: A rightward shift, facilitating the release of oxygen to the tissues.

options.label: C
options.text: No significant shift in the curve.

options.label: D
options.text: A shift that primarily affects the loading of oxygen in the lungs.

questions.correct_answer: B. A rightward shift, facilitating the release of oxygen to the tissues.

questions.text: The Hering-Breuer inflation reflex is a protective mechanism that is activated during breathing. What is the primary stimulus and the resulting response of this reflex?

options.label: A
options.text: Stimulus: Low arterial PO2; Response: Increased respiratory rate.

options.label: B
options.text: Stimulus: High arterial PCO2; Response: Increased tidal volume.

options.label: C
options.text: Stimulus: Lung inflation detected by stretch receptors; Response: Inhibition of further inspiration.

options.label: D
options.text: Stimulus: Irritants in the airway; Response: Cough or bronchoconstriction.

questions.correct_answer: C. Stimulus: Lung inflation detected by stretch receptors; Response: Inhibition of further inspiration.

questions.text: A mountaineer acclimatizing to an altitude of 14,000 feet will experience several physiological changes. Which of the following is a key early adaptation that directly enhances gas exchange?

options.label: A
options.text: Increased production of red blood cells (polycythemia)

options.label: B
options.text: A respiratory acidosis due to CO2 retention.

options.label: C
options.text: Hyperventilation leading to respiratory alkalosis.

options.label: D
options.text: A leftward shift in the oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve.

questions.correct_answer: C. Hyperventilation leading to respiratory alkalosis.

questions.text: A patient is treated with an ACE inhibitor for hypertension. By blocking the production of angiotensin II, this drug causes vasodilation of the efferent arteriole. How will the tubuloglomerular feedback mechanism respond to a primary increase in GFR resulting from this vasodilation?

options.label: A
options.text: The macula densa will sense decreased NaCl delivery and signal for afferent arteriole vasodilation.

options.label: B
options.text: The macula densa will sense increased NaCl delivery and signal for afferent arteriole vasoconstriction.

options.label: C
options.text: The juxtaglomerular cells will release more renin in response to the increased GFR.

options.label: D
options.text: The mechanism will be inhibited, leading to a further increase in GFR.

questions.correct_answer: B. The macula densa will sense increased NaCl delivery and signal for afferent arteriole vasoconstriction.

questions.text: An arterial blood gas (ABG) analysis from a patient with a severe anxiety attack shows the following: pH = 7.52, PaCO2 = 28 mmHg, HCO3- = 24 mEq/L. Based on these values, what is the primary acid-base disturbance?

options.label: A
options.text: Metabolic acidosis with respiratory compensation.

options.label: B
options.text: Respiratory acidosis.

options.label: C
options.text: Metabolic alkalosis.

options.label: D
options.text: Acute respiratory alkalosis.

questions.correct_answer: D. Acute respiratory alkalosis.

questions.text: An ECG tracing shows that the PR interval progressively lengthens with each beat until a QRS complex is dropped completely. The cycle then repeats. This pattern is characteristic of which type of atrioventricular (AV) block?

options.label: A
options.text: First-degree AV block

options.label: B
options.text: Second-degree AV block, Mobitz type I (Wenckebach)

options.label: C
options.text: Second-degree AV block, Mobitz type II

options.label: D
options.text: Third-degree (complete) AV block

questions.correct_answer: B. Second-degree AV block, Mobitz type I (Wenckebach)

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with central obesity, purple striae, and hypertension. A low-dose dexamethasone suppression test fails to suppress cortisol. A subsequent high-dose dexamethasone suppression test also fails to suppress cortisol, and her plasma ACTH level is found to be very low. What is the most likely diagnosis?

options.label: A
options.text: Cushing's disease (pituitary adenoma)

options.label: B
options.text: Ectopic ACTH-producing tumor

options.label: C
options.text: Adrenal adenoma

options.label: D
options.text: Iatrogenic Cushing's syndrome

questions.correct_answer: C. Adrenal adenoma

questions.text: A patient with cardiogenic shock is given dobutamine, a beta-1 adrenergic receptor agonist. Activation of the beta-1 receptor in cardiac myocytes leads to an increase in heart rate and contractility primarily through which of the following second messenger pathways?

options.label: A
options.text: Activation of a Gq protein, leading to an increase in IP3 and DAG.

options.label: B
options.text: Activation of a Gs protein, leading to an increase in cyclic AMP (cAMP).

options.label: C
options.text: Activation of a Gi protein, leading to a decrease in cyclic AMP (cAMP).

options.label: D
options.text: Activation of the receptor tyrosine kinase pathway.

questions.correct_answer: B. Activation of a Gs protein, leading to an increase in cyclic AMP (cAMP).
